title: How to Make Orange Cinnamon and Clove Mead

steps.headline: Dissolve honey in some warm or boiling water.
steps.description: Let it cool and put in carboy.

steps.headline: Wash orange well to remove any pesticides or wild yeast strains and slice in eighths
Put in raisins, clove, cinnamon stick, any optional ingredients and fill to 3 inches (7.6 cm) from the top with cold water.
Shake the heck out of the jug with the top on.
steps.description: Oxygen is vital to yeast prior to fermentation. Afterwards it can spoil the mead.

steps.headline: Add (or pitch) yeast when the mead is about 75 °F (24 °C) to 65 °F (18 °C), while the mead is at room temperature.
steps.description: Yeast and nutrients can help, but mead is usually fine "as is". Mead and Wine yeasts work best. Bread yeast may produce slightly off-flavors but will work ok.  Making a starter for your yeast isn't necessary, but you can tell easily if the yeast is still good if it's been in storage.

steps.headline: Install water airlock.
steps.description: Put it in cool place. It will start working within hours. After major foaming stops in a few days add some water and then keep your hands off of it. Leave the mead alone but it is okay to open your cabinet to smell every once in a while.

steps.headline: Put a hose in with a small cloth filter on the end into the clear part and siphon off the golden nectar.
steps.description: If you wait long enough even the oranges will sink to the bottom. If it is clear it is ready.

steps.headline: If you were successful, then enjoy your mead.
steps.description: When you get ready to make a different mead you will probably have to unlearn some of these practices. This recipe and procedure works with these ingredients so don't knock it. Sometimes, even the experts can forget all they know and make a good ancient mead.

text: Dissolve honey in some warm or boiling water. Let it cool and put in carboy. Wash orange well to remove any pesticides or wild yeast strains and slice in eighths  Add orange (rinds included)  Put in raisins, clove, cinnamon stick, any optional ingredients and fill to 3 inches (7.6 cm) from the top with cold water.  Shake the heck out of the jug with the top on. Oxygen is vital to yeast prior to fermentation. Afterwards it can spoil the mead. Add (or pitch) yeast when the mead is about 75 °F (24 °C) to 65 °F (18 °C), while the mead is at room temperature. Yeast and nutrients can help, but mead is usually fine "as is". Mead and Wine yeasts work best. Bread yeast may produce slightly off-flavors but will work ok.  Making a starter for your yeast isn't necessary, but you can tell easily if the yeast is still good if it's been in storage. Install water airlock. Put it in cool place. It will start working within hours. After major foaming stops in a few days add some water and then keep your hands off of it. Leave the mead alone but it is okay to open your cabinet to smell every once in a while. Put a hose in with a small cloth filter on the end into the clear part and siphon off the golden nectar. If you wait long enough even the oranges will sink to the bottom. If it is clear it is ready. If you were successful, then enjoy your mead. When you get ready to make a different mead you will probably have to unlearn some of these practices. This recipe and procedure works with these ingredients so don't knock it. Sometimes, even the experts can forget all they know and make a good ancient mead.
